questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following receptors is a ligand-gated ion channel?
questions.explanation:
718 
Sold by @itachibot The 5-HT3 receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel receptor. It rapidly depolarizes nerve endings by 
opening the cation channels located within the receptor. The 5-HT3 receptors are located in the GI tract (vagal & splanchnic afferents) and the brain 
(nucleus tractus solitarius & area postrema) and are involved in the emetic response. 
Hence 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like ondansetron, dolasetron etc are used as antiemetics. All other 5-HT receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false regarding triptans?

options.b: No action on adrenergic or cholinergic or dopaminergic receptors
options.d: They are used for prophylaxis of migraine

questions.explanation:
Triptans are not used in prophylaxis of migraine. They are indicated in the management of acute 
attacks of migraine. Drugs used in prophylaxis of migraine are : • Beta-blocker - Propranolol, metoprolol • Antidepressant - Amitriptyline, nortriptyline • Anticonvulsant - Topiramate, valproate • Serotonergic drug - Pizotifen • Antihistamine - Flunarizine • Angiotensin receptor blocker - candesartan

questions.question:
Question 3: A 25-year-old patient presented to the ER with an acute attack of migraine. †ou decide to 
administer a long-acting triptan. Which among the following do you choose?
questions.explanation:
Frovatriptan is a long-acting triptan among other triptans. Headache recurrences in an attack are less with longer-acting triptans like frovatriptan and 
naratriptan but onset of action may be slow.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient of migraine has come to the OPD for follow up. She tells you that she gets very 
nauseous during the attacks and is not being able to take the oral drug. †ou decide to 
prescribe an intranasal formulation instead. Which of the following antimigraine agents will 
you not choose? 713 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Naratriptan is not available for intranasal administration. It is available only for oral 
administration.

questions.question:
Question 5: After the administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nausea 
and vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness at the tips of her fingers that 
eventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated?
questions.explanation:
Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects 
of dihydroergotamine. The numbness progressing to bluish discolouration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. 
It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. This is a rare adverse effect of 719 
Sold by @itachibot dihydroergotamine. Contraindications for ergotamine: • Peripheral vascular disease • Coronary artery disease • Uncontrolled hypertension • Fever and/or sepsis • Pregnancy • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient has just been diagnosed with migraine. Which of the following drugs can you 
prescribe for prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
Topiramate is used in the prophylaxis of migraine. Long-term use of topiramate can cause weight 
loss. The drugs that have been approved by the FDA for the preventive treatment of migraine include: • Propranolol • Timolol • Sodium valproate • Topiramate Options A and B - Sumatriptan, a 5HT1B/1D agonist is a first-line agent for the termination of 
acute attacks. Ergotamines are also used in the termination of acute attacks. Option C - Domperidone is indicated as an adjuvant in acute attacks. Acute attacks are associated 
with gastric stasis and an increased incidence of nausea and vomiting. It is helpful in reducing 
gastrointestinal effects. It can also increase gastrointestinal absorption of other antimigraine 
agents that are not absorbed due to gastric stasis.

questions.question: Question 7: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine?

options.d: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.explanation:
Colchicine acts by binding to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration. Colchicine produces its anti-inflammatory effects by binding to the intracellular protein tubulin. 
This prevents the polymerization of tubulin into microtubules which is necessary for leukocyte 
migration and phagocytosis. Inhibition of microtubule formation prevents granulocyte migration 
and also arrests cell division at G1 phase.

questions.question:
Question 8: 714 
Sold by @itachibot Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.explanation:
Colchicine inhibits neutrophil (granulocyte) recruitment. 720 
Sold by @itachibot Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerisation of microtubules by binding to tubulin. This 
reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic 
factors by activated neutrophils, thus reducing the inflammatory response overall. Colchicine is used in gout and Mediterranean fever.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with chronic tophaceous gout was prescribed sulfinpyrazone. What is the 
mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Sulfinpyrazone is a uricosuric agent that promotes excretion of uric acid. It is used to decrease the 
body pool of urate in patients with gout. They act by inhibiting the organic anion transporter that 
is involved in uric acid reabsorption in renal tubules. Uricosuric agents used in gout are: • Probenecid • Sulfinpyrazone • Benzbromarone • Lesinurad Uricosuric therapy should be initiated in gouty patients with underexcretion of uric acid and when 
allopurinol or febuxostat is contraindicated or when tophi are present. Therapy should not be 
started until 2–3 weeks after an acute attack.

questions.question:
Question 10: A middle-aged obese man has presented to the OPD with acute pain around his left first 
metatarsophalangeal joint. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. X-ray is given 
below. Which drug is commonly used as initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the X-ray showing Martel's sign point towards a diagnosis of acute on 
chronic presentation of gout. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout. In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit 
urate crystal phagocytosis. Option A - Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is 
uricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated. Option C - Allopurinol is used for prophylaxis of gout. Option D - NSAIDs are selected over colchicine because of troublesome diarrhea associated with 
colchicine.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was diagnosed with tumour lysis syndrome. She was 
administered rasburicase. Which group does this drug belong to?
questions.explanation:
Rasburicase is a recombinant urate oxidase which converts uric acid into soluble and inactive 
allantoin. It is more effective in reducing the urate level than allopurinol. Recombinant uric acid oxidase is available as rasburicase and pegloticase. It is produced by 
genetically modified Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain. They are indicated in gout only for chronic 
refractory gout. It is primarily indicated for hyperuricemia associated with tumor lysis syndrome. 721 
Sold by @itachibot Pegloticase is a recombinant pegylated uric acid oxidase that is indicated for treatment of severe, 
treatment-refractory, chronic gout and also prophylaxis of gout.

questions.question:
Question 12: †ou have prescribed the first-line urate-lowering drug to a patient with chronic gout. Which 
of the following is true about this drug?
questions.explanation:
Allopurinol is recommended as the first-line urate-lowering agent in all patients with gout. It is 
a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase enzyme. It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid 
levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. The metabolite of allopurinol called 
oxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient was on treatment with indomethacin for gout. †ou decide to add a non-purine 
xanthine oxidase inhibitor to his treatment plan. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Febuxostat is a non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is indicated for reducing hyperuricemia 
in chronic gout. Both allopurinol and febuxostat can be used as first line agents but since the 
question mentions a non-purine inhibitor is chosen, febuxostat is the answer. Option A - Allopurinol is a purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor. Option D - Sulfinpyrazone is a uricosuric agent.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient, who is a known case of gout on treatment with allopurinol, comes to the OPD for 
follow up. His serum uric acid level is 11 mg/dl. †ou add lesinurad to his treatment regime for 716 
Sold by @itachibot adequate disease control. Which group does this drug belong to?
questions.explanation:
Lesinurad is a uricosuric agent. It is a URAT1 inhibitor indicated in combination with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor for the 
treatment of hyperuricemia associated with gout. By inhibiting URAT1, it increases the urinary 
excretion of uric acid.

questions.question: Question 15: What is pegloticase used for?
questions.explanation:
Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout. Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid 
into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other 
urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.question:
Question 16: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous 
history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine 
might have caused this presentation?
questions.explanation:
722 
Sold by @itachibot The patient may have been given sumatriptan, a 5-HT1b/1d receptor agonist which causes 
vasoconstriction and used in migraine. Thus, sumatriptan will worsen angina by causing coronary 
vasoconstriction. Angina will be worsened if the O2 demand of the heart is increased or there is reduced blood flow 
to the already ischemic areas.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in gout?
questions.explanation:
Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. The drug of choice in an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) 
like indomethacin or the drug colchicine. Colchicine is poorly tolerated and should not be used 
in elderly patients with chronic kidney disease. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout. In addition to inhibiting 
prostaglandin synthase, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis Intraarticular steroids like triamcinolone or methylprednisolone can also be given. Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric only 
at higher doses that are poorly tolerated.

questions.question:
Question 18: 717 
Sold by @itachibot A patient was prescribed erenumab-aooe for the prophylaxis of migraine. What is the 
mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Erenumab-aooe is a calcitonin gene related protein (CGRP) receptor antagonist approved for the 
prophylaxis of migraine. The pathology of migraine is not completely understood but it includes activation of trigeminal 
ganglion nociceptive neurons and the subsequent release of CGRP from fibers associated with 
meningeal vessels. This is believed to mediate vasodilation and mast cell degranulation. Thus, 
CGRP is involved in the development and maintenance of persistent pain, central sensitization 
and allodynia, which are events characteristic of migraine pathology. Blockage of CGRP receptors by CGRP receptor antagonists, causes inhibition of the inflammatory 
and nociceptive effects of CGRP at multiple sites within the peripheral and central nervous 
systems that are implicated in the underlying pathology of migraine. Monoclonal antibodies that directly inhibit CGRP have also been developed. These include: • Fremanezumab • Galcanezumab Note: The FDA has recently approved Atogepant, a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor 
antagonist for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in adults. The recommended dosage 
is 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg orally once daily. In severe renal impairment or end-stage renal disease 
it is 10 mg once daily. 723 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-rheumatoid drugs
